title: From Barron’s, September 30, 2019 (Part 1)
text:
[Italics-bold within the brackets are my additions/elaborations] [New M* Discussions doesn’t allow any colors for cut-and-paste from WORD]

MW Cover: Tate Sullivan [ Maxim Group ] has raised Q3 estimates for several industrials – ABM, AEGN, BMI, EME, NVEE.

Pg M3, Trader: The impeachment news didn’t affect the market but the news that the US may delist Chinese companies from the US exchanges [and other possible restrictions] did. The bulls may look at the market near all-time highs despite recent bad news, while the bears may look at the double-top. The Q3 earnings season starts mid-October.

Wells Fargo [WFC] has a new CEO Charles Scharf, the former CEO and President of BONY-Mellon [BK]. He will remain in NYC – WFC is based in San Francisco and has extensive operations in Charlotte, NC. His tasks will include lifting the asset cap imposed by the Fed in February 2018, repair customer relationships, cut costs, improve earnings, probably in that order.

HFTs and market-makers are often blamed during the periods of market volatility. But the data doesn’t support this according to a study by Citadel Securities that examined bid-ask spreads in the order books of 13 US exchanges for all SP500 and R2000 stocks since mid-2011. The conclusion is that the bid-ask spreads have declined for small orders but have remained the same for large orders. The sources of liquidity have changed.

[The CME FedWatch tool, based on current fed fund futures quotes, shows the following probabilities for 2019:

For 3rd hike [cut],

0% for hike [44.9% for cut] at FOMC 10/30/19;

0% for hike [69.3% for cut] at FOMC 12/11/19;

http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html ]

For the week [index changes only], DJIA -0.43%, SP500 -1.01%, Nasdaq Comp -2.19%, Russell 2000 -2.52%. DJ Transports -1.08%; DJ Utilities +1.57%. US$ +0.88%, oil/WTI -3.75%, gold -0.54%.

YTD [index changes only], DJIA +14.97%, SP500 +18.15%, Nasdaq Comp +19.66%.

Pg M6, Europe: Compagnie Financiere Richmont [CFRHF; fwd P/E 21] has negative outlook on HK [11% sales] and China [40% sales]. exposures. Brands include Cartier , Clash , Cyrille Vigneron , Van Cleef & Arpels , Dunhill , Montblanc , Yoox Net-a-Porter , Purdey .

Pg M6, Emerging Markets: Several Asian battery companies will benefit from electric-vehicle [EV] demand. Five of the top six EV battery companies are S Korean [ LG Chemical , Samsung SDI , SK Innovations ], Chinese [CATL, BYD], Japanese [ Panasonic ]. Demand will outpace supply in 3 years. EV manufacturing will also become profitable. EU carbon-emission rules will benefit EVs from 2021. Several of these stocks have been hurt by Chinese reduction in state subsidies for EVs.

Pg M9, Commodities: Silver [+17% QTD] and nickel [+36% QTD] have outperformed gold recently. Indonesia has banned nickel-ore export from 1/1/20. Silver and gold are benefitting from economic and political uncertainty. Silver to gold ratio peaked at 95 in July [i.e. silver became too cheap relative to gold].

Pg M7, Options: Netflix [NFLX] is now a fallen FAANG due to fears of competition from AAPL, DIS, etc. Bulls may bet on rebound by selling puts.

[SP500 VIX 17.22, SKEW 116.61] [10-Yr TYVIX 5.34] [Yahoo Finance data]

Pg M26, M32: A down week in Europe [UK +0.73%, Norway -2.34] and a bad week in Asia [India +1.52%, China -3.85%]. The equity CEF index [data to Thursday] outperformed the DJIA and its discount was -5%.

Treasury rates 3-mo yield 1.80%, 2-yr 1.63%, 5-yr 1.56%, 10-yr 1.69%, 30-yr 2.13% [Treasury data*]. Dollar rose, DXY 99.13, +0.7% [M35]. Gold fell tot $1,490, -0.8%; the gold-miners rose [M34]. [^XAU was at 91.07, -3.73% for the week]

*Treasury Yield-Curve https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/interest-rates/Pages/TextView.aspx?data=y...

Top FDIC insured savings deposit rates*: Money-market accounts 2.23%; 1-yr CDs 2.28%; 5-yr CDs 2.76% [M33].

*For local rates https://www.depositaccounts.com/banks/rates-map/

Pg 16: Cover Story, “The Future of Biotech: Our Roundtable Experts Pick 15 Promising Stocks” This may be a golden age for biotech innovations but there been outflows from biotech funds and the biotech index is down -25% from mid-2015 peak. There have been many biotech IPOs, there have been some drug disappointments and drug pricing has become an issue. Biotech stocks are very volatile. Elections create additional uncertainty on regulations. Challenges remain in moving from labs to production and distribution. Several startups and smaller companies get acquired by more established companies.

Gabol Amusa, Chardan Capital : RGNX, QURE, KRYS, MGTX, MDCO, KOD

Ziad Bakri, PRHSX: VTRX, ASND, TCDA

Eli Casdin, Casdin Capital : BLFS, MGTA, NVTA, MYOK

David Schenkein, GV -GOOGL: Verve , Beam , Verana

Gena Wang, Barclays : RGNX, SRPT

Biotech ETF IBB

Biotech OEFs FBIOX, FBDIX, PRHSX, VGHCX

Pg 3, Up & Down Wall Street: Bull markets climb a wall of worry and that wall is getting bigger. Most recent additions were ideas to curb the US investments in China; limit pension fund investments in Chinese stocks; delisting of Chinese companies from the US exchanges. Now the Chinese companies listed in the US are exempt from some disclosure rules by the SEC [a bad idea] and that could change. Chinese stocks and ETFs fell sharply. But few of these ideas may come to fruition.

Cracks began to appear in the IPO market. The money-market repo market ran low on cash and the Fed started pumping liquidity in that market. Impeachment was in the news. Jobs growth has slowed – this Friday’s jobs report is expected to add +150,000 when the 12-mo average is +173,000.

State and local pension funds are only 52% funded. The assumed median return is high at 7.25% and many are forced to take higher risks. Stephanie Pomboy [ MacroMaven ] and Harley Bassman [ Convexity Maven ] suggest printing money or the Fed QE as solution. The new MMT may also be deployed. Gold and real assets may benefit.

Pg 5, Streetwise: Many companies are burning-cash [PTON (latest IPO), SNAP, WORK, TSLA, NFLX, etc]. Percentage of IPOs now that are unprofitable is similar to that during the dot.com bubble although the overall IPO valuations are not that crazy. Instead, many companies talk about their “path to profitability” several years down the road. [Piece talks about cash-burn as well as no-profits; AMZN is given as an example with no-profits but huge positive cash flows].

More later….

YBB
